Review: Extra half-star for that absolutely epic final sequence. Also I'm glad for the Philippines? After what Spain did?

Fascinated by how low I'd let my expectations get when this was just so damn fun. I didn't even want the introductory Brooklyn part to end, but of course it was a delight to skip from mushroom to mushroom. Lots of treats for the audience to enjoy. Nihilistic Luma was funny for a line or two, but that's really it—don't do Rosalina's ilk like that.

Had so much fun, and I was moved by this film in ways I could never have anticipated. The open vulnerability, the criticism of the government, the hope and the pain and the hope and of course 最後の一匹 (the strangely touching epithet given to Godzilla at the end of the original film, it's stuck with me forever).
Horrible, beautiful. Ends in the assumed dreamspace that we are told Chinatown is, but it is cold reality that left me silent for an hour after the film ended.

Movie: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
Review: Just as utterly bizarre as the book, to the letter. Compelling throughout which helps with the unreal length. This film (and story overall) really highlights how uncanny and hamfisted it feels to tell a dystopian story in a dystopian world. Can't see what Snow's story really has to do with anything—he could have become just the same person without his involvement with the tenth Hunger Games and Lucy Gray (who I do love).
Ellis is a very pushy man, but this was such a charming movie otherwise, a jewel in the dark.
Haunts me. The only joy to be had is in that little moment before Joe and Betty hit the false city background they are walking towards on the sets.
Exhausting, depressing, wild, immensely well-acted, portrait of '80s etc etc
filmically, the sheer power of those favored few songs you keep on repeat
The fragment of a Mary Oliver poem but as a film and a little (!) deeper—'Tell me, what is it you plan to do with your one wild and precious life?'
What's there to say? Beautiful portrayal, hurts all the time. Filmed in early 2001 in what the filmmaker describes as a relatively peaceful moment before later 2001/2002 and even this breaks me.
